title: Food Poisoning in Dogs: What to Know
author: Shishira Sreenivas

content: If your dog has an upset stomach or is feeling ill, they may have food poisoning.

It happens more often in dogs than you’d think. Lots of things in your kitchen, like raw meat and fish, old eggs, or moldy cheese are breeding grounds for dangerous bacteria or fungi. These include E. coli , salmonella, staphylococcus, and others.
While your dog can bounce back quickly from most things, a trip to the animal hospital may be necessary. Here’s what you need to know.

content_blocks.text: If your dog has an upset stomach or is feeling ill, they may have food poisoning.

It happens more often in dogs than you’d think. Lots of things in your kitchen, like raw meat and fish, old eggs, or moldy cheese are breeding grounds for dangerous bacteria or fungi. These include E. coli , salmonella, staphylococcus, and others.
While your dog can bounce back quickly from most things, a trip to the animal hospital may be necessary. Here’s what you need to know.

sections.heading: Signs to Watch Out For
content: There’s generally a short amount of time between when your dog eats contaminated food and when they start showing a physical reaction. The symptoms and severity of food poisoning depend on the type of bacteria.
In severe cases, your dog may have:
bullets: Dizziness or inability to walk normally
Cramping or pain when the stomach/ abdomen is touched

content_blocks.text: There’s generally a short amount of time between when your dog eats contaminated food and when they start showing a physical reaction. The symptoms and severity of food poisoning depend on the type of bacteria.

associated_bullets: Dizziness or inability to walk normally
Cramping or pain when the stomach/ abdomen is touched

content_blocks.text: In severe cases, your dog may have:

sections.heading: What to Do if You Think Your Dog Has Food Poisoning
content: Call your vet if you think your dog has food poisoning. They can direct you to the best place/resource.
You may need to go to an animal hospital right away if their symptoms are getting worse or haven’t improved in a few hours.

content_blocks.text: Call your vet if you think your dog has food poisoning. They can direct you to the best place/resource.
You may need to go to an animal hospital right away if their symptoms are getting worse or haven’t improved in a few hours.

sections.heading: How to Protect Your Pooch
content: Follow these tips to keep your dog safe:
bullets: Make sure your trash cans and waste baskets are tightly covered.
Toss old foods from your fridge.
Don’t leave your dog without supervision for too long.
Check for expiration dates on your dog foods.
Watch out for any pet food recalls.
Always check ingredient lists for any dangerous foods.
Don’t forget to wash your hands after touching raw meat or eggs.

sources: ASPCA: “People Foods Pets Should Never Eat,” “Animal Poison Control.”
FDA: “Good Dog, Bad Food: Foods for People That Are Bad for Your Dog,” “Potentially Dangerous Items for Your Pet.”
American Kennel Club: “Can Dogs Get Food Poisoning?”
meta_description: Dogs can get food poisoning, too. Learn the signs, what to do if it happens, and ways to protect your pooch.
